content.raw: How about we leave it out for now, and ticket an issue about joint visualization for the SDF parser? I think there are several things to be considered before implementing this, for example, when using the SDF parser to view a preview of a model before it is inserted on the server, it's best for performance that we don't generate joints. The same goes for the other visualizations you're adding. Do you think it's ok to keep this pull request about loading files?
content.html: How about we leave it out for now, and ticket an issue about joint visualization for the SDF parser? I think there are several things to be considered before implementing this, for example, when using the SDF parser to view a preview of a model before it is inserted on the server, it's best for performance that we don't generate joints. The same goes for the other visualizations you're adding. Do you think it's ok to keep this pull request about loading files?

Okay sound good, I think removing it would be the best option now, so this PR is clean as possible.

content.raw: We should investigate why this is not working during testing
content.html: We should investigate why this is not working during testing

content.raw:
I did some investigation when I encountered the problem, it has sth to do with the fact that we are not using the real `DOM`, remember in the `gui_test` where we had to use the `fixture.html` to be able to test the buttons and the `DOM` stuff, same problem I believe.

That is why I use trying to add `PhantomJS`, it would solve this, but apparently if we test using `PhantomJS` we will have to deal with the fact that `phantomJS` doesn't support `WebGL` at the moment and we will have to add some hacks to make it work :confused: 

`WebGL would require an OpenGL-capable system. Since the goal of PhantomJS is to become 100% headless and self-contained, this is not acceptable. Using OpenGL emulation via Mesa can overcome the limitation, but then the performance would degrade.`
content.html:
I did some investigation when I encountered the problem, it has sth to do with the fact that we are not using the real DOM, remember in the gui_test where we had to use the fixture.html to be able to test the buttons and the DOM stuff, same problem I believe.

That is why I use trying to add PhantomJS, it would solve this, but apparently if we test using PhantomJS we will have to deal with the fact that phantomJS doesn't support WebGL at the moment and we will have to add some hacks to make it work

WebGL would require an OpenGL-capable system. Since the goal of PhantomJS is to become 100% headless and self-contained, this is not acceptable. Using OpenGL emulation via Mesa can overcome the limitation, but then the performance would degrade.

content.raw: So the OBJ loader takes all the files, but the collada loader only takes the first file. Is this because the OBJ loader will handle `obj` and `mtl`?  How about textures which the collada file may need, do we have a way to load them?

content.raw:
Yes :) the Obj loader take the `mlt` and the `obj`.

And  yes we do handle textures, well this is still in a separate branch because it relays on a newer Threejs version, the `dev` one, I believe adding it in a separate PR would be safer.
content.html:
Yes :) the Obj loader take the mlt and the obj.

And yes we do handle textures, well this is still in a separate branch because it relays on a newer Threejs version, the dev one, I believe adding it in a separate PR would be safer.

content.raw: humm I think that if an OBJ string is passed, we shouldn't even touch a file given by the URI. What if they are different?

content.raw: you mean the file name and the URI?
content.html: you mean the file name and the URI?

content.raw:
So like, you would pass both the OBJ file URI and the OBJ file's contents, right? For example:

~~~
loadMeshFromString('assets/XXX.obj', undefined, undefined, function(mesh){}, 
    ['# 3ds Max Wavefront OBJ Exporter v0.97b - (c)2007 guruware
    # File Created: 30.11.2016 17:17:21
    mtllib mesh.mtl
    #
    # object Walkway_45_Right
    #
    v  -762.0001 1077.6306 -0.1269
    ..........
    ']);
~~~

In this case, I'd assume whatever I passed to `files` will be loaded. So I'm not sure why the code would ever go read `assets/XXX.obj`.
content.html:
So like, you would pass both the OBJ file URI and the OBJ file's contents, right? For example:

loadMeshFromString('assets/XXX.obj', undefined, undefined, function(mesh){}, 
    ['# 3ds Max Wavefront OBJ Exporter v0.97b - (c)2007 guruware
    # File Created: 30.11.2016 17:17:21
    mtllib mesh.mtl
    #
    # object Walkway_45_Right
    #
    v  -762.0001 1077.6306 -0.1269
    ..........
    ']);

In this case, I'd assume whatever I passed to files will be loaded. So I'm not sure why the code would ever go read assets/XXX.obj.

content.raw:
Oh now I remember why I didn't remove the Uri :sweat_smile: 

The model Uri is concluded from the model's sdf, so there is no need to remove it, because it is just something internal.

It would be useful if we wanted to load a model using both the `string` api and the `Uri`'s one, I believe leaving it would allow us to do so.
content.html:
Oh now I remember why I didn't remove the Uri

The model Uri is concluded from the model's sdf, so there is no need to remove it, because it is just something internal.

It would be useful if we wanted to load a model using both the string api and the Uri's one, I believe leaving it would allow us to do so.

content.raw:
They are different functions, so there is no way for a person looking at this one to know they should look at the other function for a deeper documentation ;)

Also, the current documentation for `loadMeshFromString` doesn't explain what's the URI's role.

We have to keep in mind that other people (or even us) might come back to this code years from now and wonder what was going on, users shouldn't need to dig through the code to understand what a parameter is supposed to do.
content.html:
They are different functions, so there is no way for a person looking at this one to know they should look at the other function for a deeper documentation ;)

Also, the current documentation for loadMeshFromString doesn't explain what's the URI's role.

We have to keep in mind that other people (or even us) might come back to this code years from now and wonder what was going on, users shouldn't need to dig through the code to understand what a parameter is supposed to do.
